reviewText: I was so happy to find this DVD! The story of brave Rikki Tikki Tavi, the brave little mongoose who kills two cobras is enchanting. The story is narrated by Orson Wells, and what a voice he had. It holds the viewer spell bound. My two grand daughters loved this story, and it is just as fresh and exciting as when I first saw it many years ago.

reviewText: I liked this adaption of the classic Rudyard Kipling story.  Orson Wells does a great job of narrating this tale of a pet mongoose who faces two cobras to defend his family.  No fancy Hollywood effects.  Just a well-told ageless story for the whole family. Might scare some young children.  Good animation.Doug SetterAuthor ofStomach FlatteningandOne Less Victim: A Prevention Guide
summary: Cool animation for adults and children

reviewText: So happy to find this classic on DVD.  My husband and I both loved Rikki when we were young and wanted to share him with our kids.  We had him on VHS before but needed to update the collection and found this DVD.  It still felt like it should and has the bonus cartoon which my little one enjoyed even though she didn't understand any of the history (yet).  Recommended!  Oh, if you've never seen the cartoon it is about a mongoose who protects his adopted family from cobras -- focuses on family and bravery and cleverness.

reviewText: My CBS-recorded copy was full of drop-outs, so I was delighted to find out this great Chuck Jones adaptation of the Kipling Jungle Book tale was finally on DVD. Although the story is animated in the usual Jones style, it has been done more in an effort to look like book illustrations. Although the mongoose is cute--much more adorable than the real thing--parents should be warned that all these Jungle Book stories have been taken word-for-word from the actual book and not from the cutesy-poo Disney flick, so the cold-and-sinister cobras and other snakes hissing about death may be frightening for very young children.Included on this DVD is the third story in Jones' Chester Cricket cycle, Yankee Doodle Cricket. I had not seen this cartoon before and was quite disappointed by it, especially after reading a review saying it was the funniest of the three. It has none of the charm and humor of the original Cricket in Times Square or the delightful silliness and holiday spirit of A Very Merry Cricket. Your mileage may vary!This DVD is practically perfect. There are some dust specks and flecks visible; however the colors and lines are bright and clean and the sound is good. The only downside to this DVD is the interminable previews that you are automatically subjected to. Hint: pressing the menu button on your DVD remote won't help, but once the previews start, you CAN skip through them by pressing the chapter button until you get to the actual menu.

reviewText: Rikki Tikki Tavi is worth twice the purchase price.  I can still remember my elementary school teachers rolling out the reel to reel projector to show it before the holiday breaks.  Reel to Reel projectors people, I'm dating myself here.  Every child in the world should be given the opportunity to view this masterpiece of animation and story telling.As for the Yankee Doodle Cricket bonus story, its cute, but its nothing compared to Rikki Tikki.  I'd pay twenty dollars for a copy of Rikki Tikki alone on DVD even at only 27 minutes, but most people don't feel that way I'm sure, thus dictating the addition of the bonus story.  The two stories are definately not of the same calibur.Buy this one for Rikki Tikki Tavi a must own of must owns.

reviewText: How long have I been waiting for Rikki Tikki Tavi to hit DVD?  How about forever!  I bought the movie the other day and brought it home and sat down in my family room with my wife and two daughters and said "This is Rikki Tikki Tavi, enjoy."  My daughters had never seen it and my wife vaguely remembered it from when she was a kid.  But I knew it was going to be a treat.  Not dissappointed, the entirely family loved it.  I cannot express mow many memories this brought back to me of my childhood where Rikki Tikki Tavi was a yearly telivision event along the lines of The Wizard Of Ozz and Willy Wonka.  My youngest daughter has watched it like 30 times since that night.  I've seen it half a dozen times as well.  It doesn't get old.  What a great Chuck Jones classic.  Yankee Doodle Cricket is like way annoying, but I can live with that.  Cricket In Times Square was far superior, but that was the 70s for you.  Orsen Wells is awesome as the narrator for Rikki Tikki.  I just remember how scary the cobras were when I was a kid.  Great show.  Great memories.  Definitely a must-have for your animated collection, rate up there with the great Disney epics.
summary: Rikki Tikk - The Rock Star Of Mongooses!!!!!

reviewText: This was one of my favorite stories when I was a kid. I had always heard of the existence of this film, and was never able to see it until the release of this DVD. Judging from those of Jones' kid-lit adaptations I had seen (the wonderfully witty "Dot and The Line" of 1965; the glorious "Grinch" of 1966; "Horton Hears A Who" [1970]; and the lovely "Cricket In Times Square" of 1976) I was expecting great things, and was largely satisfied. The music and the writing ("oh Rikki-Tikki,you ARE brave and beautiful!") tend to be a tad cloying. But these are minor cavils: the tone is, by and large, splendidly consistent. A good deal of the Kipling text is used, and Orson Welles reads it with terrific brio. The voice characterizations,particularly those of June Foray, are as note-perfect as one could wish. The 4:3 transfer is decent, the mono sound perfectly adequate. The color is not as brilliant as it might be, but I suspect the source material and transfer are not to blame for this. It must be said, finally, that the production staff Jones had at his studio in 1975 were not as capableof sustained flights of visual fancy as the staff Jones had at MGM only ten years earlier. Many of those artists were veteransof the great Warner Bros. period, and were thus linked to a great tradition. The visual scheme in the "Rikki Tikki" film is pleasant enough, but one misses, for example, the almost manic inspiration of Gerry Chiniquy or Maurice Noble. In short: this is a terrific film by anyone else's standards, but alongside Jones' best work it must be judged a mixed bag. Still, it contains some of the finest character and action animation in any Jones film, and no animation afficionado should miss it for this reason, as well as the pleasure of seeing a great story told very well indeed.
summary: Typically fine and faithful Jones adaptation of a classic

reviewText: I saw "Rikki Tikki Tavi" when I was 10, the first year it was aired on TV: 1975(it was not 1972, as noted above). This was at a time when this kind of programming was starting to crank down, sadly. At this same time, Rankin/Bass productions were still presenting Christmas faire, although not up to their 60s offerings: "Rudolph...", "The Little Drummer Boy", the original "Frosty...", and "Santa Claus is Comin' to Town". At this time, as well, Rankin/Bass released what remains as the one version of "The Hobbit". Chuck Jones' debut of "Rikki..." was preceeded by, on the same evening, Jones' short version of "The Jungle Book" entitled "Mowgli's Brothers", which is really the other impressive short of Jones' "Jungle Book" ones. My brother and I were amazed, though, at "Rikki", this being a great 20 minute short - with Orson Welles narrating! Get it at a decent price, though, for "Yankee Doodle Cricket" isn't much. To critique a review here, this program is fine for kids above the age of 8 or 9, but not 3(and "No", I'm not being "old-fashioned"). I mean, we're talking frightening cobras here. They're animated, but these are still pretty powerful images-even at my ripe old age. Beware of unsensitive reviewers from the baby boom era!Update as of April 2014: a more recent repackaging, at still a great price (!) now added all the "Cricket" tales - "Cricket in Times Square" and "Very Merry Cricket" - and the rest of the "Jungle Book" tales - "Mowgli's Brothers" (nice!) and "The White Seal". "Rikki" and "Mowgli" are definitely the best of the group, but with Mowgli not on the previous collection - and the price still reasonable - these are most assuredly a great compilation of late Chuck Jones. That alone makes it worth it! However, the set truly is enjoyable - and for those of us who were children back then, even more so. It's just nice to have a chance to view a part of our childhood that actually DOES stand the test of time, with so much of it just romanticized in our childish little minds. Go for this latter set!
summary: Great Chuck Jones is better than anything modern

reviewText: I absolutely loved Rikki Tikki as a kid.  It came on every year and i could not wait.  It was kinda scary for a six year old, but i loved it.  Orsen Wells voice is so elegant and warm and the animation, though not Disney standards, was well done.  The story is about Rikki Tikki's love for a boy and lengths he goes through to save he and his family from the Cobra's in the graden.  The sitar background music is perfect and you get a real feel for Kipling and his love of India.  Yankee Doodle is cute, but really you'd be buying this for Rikki Tikki.  Highly recommended
Title: N/A

reviewText: While aimed at a younger audience (5-10), these two animated features is good viewing for all ages.  Rikki Tikki is a fine retelling of a classic children's story with strong moral overtones.  Yankee Doodle Cricket is a recreation of the founding of our country with a group of patriotic critters leading the charge.  Both features are short enough to not drive a parent crazy as it plays over and over.  A nice change from dancing elves and singing dinosaurs.
